awd_titl_txt: Conjugated Energy Transport and Hot Carrier Diffusion in 2D Transition Metal Dichalcogenides: Novel Characterization toward Fundamental Understanding
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are materials that have an extremely small thickness (down to a few atoms level). They have broad applications including flexible circuits, sensors, and low power transistors. Their thermophysical properties and energy transport capability directly determine their performance and durability. Also, their electron transfer rate is a property that directly determines device functionality. This project uses ultrafast lasers and a continuous laser to excite and probe the molecular vibrations modes (Raman spectroscopic signal) of TMDs, and use such signals to distinguish and characterize the thermophysical properties, electron transfer rate, and interface energy transfer capability. The outcome of the project should establish the critical knowledge base needed in TMDs structure tailoring, device design, and thermal optimization. Furthermore, the project integrates research activities into education via classroom teaching and new class module development, fosters minority student research training, and stimulates research interests of K-12 students by various outreach activities including science fair, lab tour, and providing high-school teacher research experience.

The goals of this project are to conduct further deployment of a novel energy transport state-resolved Raman to characterize hot carrier diffusivity, phonon thermal conductivity, interface thermal resistance for supported TMDs, and electron-hole nonradiative recombination coefficient for monolayered TMDs. The project investigates the effect of physical structure on the three transport processes: hot carrier diffustion, in-plane phonon transport, and cross-interface energy transport (for supported TMDs), studies the effect of substrate on properties, and explores the effect of temperature (70 K to 850 K) on properties as well. This represents the first and high precision consideration of hot carrier transport and radiative electron-hole recombination in 2D materials. This project significantly promotes the field of defect engineering in 2D TMDs, and provides frontier perspective on the challenges and opportunities in this emerging field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project is targeting some of the critical problems faced in characterizing thermophysical properties of 2D materials: conjugated phonon and hot carriers transport. The project is designed to achieve four objectives: 1) conduct further development of a novel energy transport state-resolved Raman (ET-Raman) technique to construct and probe continuous wave (CW), nanosecond (ns) and picosecond (ps) energy transport states, to distinguish and measure the hot carrier diffusivity (D), phonon thermal conductivity (k), interface thermal resistance (R) for supported transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), and electron-hole nonradiative recombination coefficient (B) for monolayer (ML) TMDs; 2) investigate the effect of physical structure on three energy transport processes: hot carrier diffustion, in-plane phonon transport, and cross-interface energy transport (for supported TMDs); 3) study the effect of substrate on (k, D, R, B), and 4) explore the effect of temperature on (k, D, R, B).

 

A ET-Raman technique has been developed that involves energy transport state design in spatial and temporal domains. Specifically the temporal domain design at steady state, ns state, and ps state allows us to precisely distinguish the effect of phonon transport and hot carrier transport, and completely eliminate the need of laser absorption and temperature rise data. This has made the Raman-based measurement of thermal conductivity and interface thermal conductance of 2D materials reach the unprecedented level accuracy. Also for the first time, we made it possible to fully consider the nonradiative electron-hole recombination coefficient, precisely determined it, and measure the interface thermal conductance of ML TMDs. Using the ET-Raman technique, the thermal conductivity of 2D materials was measured from room temperature down to 77 K for the first time. Also based on our thermal reffusivity theory, we determined the thermal reffusivity at the 0 K limit, and determined the in-plane structural thermal domain size of 2D materials. This physical size is critical to understanding 2D materials' transport properties, but has never been measured and understood before. Because of their extremely small crosssectional size, 2D materials' in-plane grain size cannot be measured using normal beam scattering techniques (neutron scattering and x-ray scattering). The structure domain size determined by the thermal reffusivity theory provides the only valuable information to evaluate the in-plane grain size of 2D materials. In our project, we realized that optical phonon (OP)-acoustic phonon (AP) thermal nonequilibirum in Raman-based thermal characterization of 2D materials plays a big role, especially when the laser intensity is very high.  Some preliminary technique development has been done to distinguish the OP and AP temperatures, and our project reported the first time ever effort and the OP-AP energy coupling factor. Our project pointed out this physical phenomenon is very complicated, yet critically important, and future research is urgently needed in this area to measure and understand the thermophysical properties of 2D materials.

 

This project has provided extensive and systematic training to seven Ph.D. students (one female) and one M.S. student on micro/nanoscale material preparation, structure characterization, Raman spectroscopy, thermal analysis, paper writing, proposal writing, and presentation. Also undergraduate students have been extensively involved in the project on micro/nanoscale thermal characterization, and some of them have continued to pursue graduate study after graduation. Also we have provided excellent training to one high school teacher on microscale thermal characterization and microscale sample preparation. More than 30 papers have been published in highly visible journals, and the graduate students have presented their work in international conferences.


Last Modified: 01/13/2024
Modified by: Xinwei Wang
